The thing about deepfakes is beyond 720p; with current technology, they are easy to prove fake. It might seem counterintuitive as a quality deepfake of 1080p appears more real to the human eye than, say, 240p, but that is how it works. 
As resolution increases, the difficulty of creating goes up exponentially. At the same time, the comparative processing power to disprove goes down linearly. No matter how perfect a 4k image is to create, it will take many times less processing power to prove it fake than creating.
So why are low resolutions easier to fake? It has to do with the number of pixels required. At low resolutions, there are far fewer items to process. At higher resolutions, far more. However, proving a fake requires only a certain number of "false" pixels to conclude validity. As the number of pixels checked increases, the percent needed to be proven "false" decreases. This makes them harder to create and easier to detect. (easier being relative to the original creation time.)
TLDR: You can fool the Human eye with massive time invested, but a computer can prove validity in a fraction of that time. Think of it like this. It took a British mathematician 15 years to calculate pi accurately to 528 places. Meanwhile, a modern Apple mac computer can calculate a million digits in 2.3 seconds. If you were presented with 1000 digits of PI and had to prove all 1000 digits, even if you had the correct version to reference, it would take you ~2.3 seconds per number.
